title: Why a Miami Developer Says Now’s the Time for ‘Hopping on a Plane’ and Starting to Shop
text:
Ryan Shear, managing partner of Property Markets Group, a development firm in Miami, New York and Chicago, has a growing portfolio of more than $4 billion worth of real estate assets, and more than 5 million square feet of residential property.

Mr. Shear, 36, recently launched the Waldorf Astoria Hotel and Residences in Downtown Miami, and was behind Echo Aventura, Echo Brickell, and X Miami, a luxury rental development.

Currently, the company is in various stages of developing properties, including 10 Sullivan, Queens Plaza South, Muse Residences, 111 Leroy Street, and 548 West 22nd Street, all in New York; as well as others in Miami and Chicago.

We caught up with the Florida native to discuss who’s still buying Florida, the value of a Miami home away from the beach, and more.

More: Architect Ricardo Álvarez-Díaz Is All About Sustainability and Resiliency

Mansion Global: Describe your dream property.

Ryan Shear: It depends on the home.For a secondary home, I’d love somewhere on the Amalfi Coast. You just can’t recreate stuff like that. The wine, the food, the cheese.

For a primary home, I really like living in Miami. It’s a really nice lifestyle. I live in a custom home in Echo Brickell.

There’s also this pocket in Miami where Madonna has a house, and where Sylvester Stallone lived. They’re hidden and it’s on a bay. You’re in the urban core, but you’re also on the open water.

MG: Do you have a real estate property that got away?

RS: You miss certain things if you’re not paying attention. There’s a site in Miami that on Brickell Avenue that another company got for a steal. It’s an old teacher’s union building.

More: Compass’s ‘Chief Evangelist’ on the Importance of a Home’s Context

MG: What does luxury mean to you?

Obviously, it starts with location, that’s the biggest driver. Then you get into things like space, and types of finishes. After location, luxury becomes a lot more subjective. It’s more about style and taste.

MG: What area do you think is the next hub for luxury properties?

RS: Everybody’s down on real estate in general, because we’re potentially headed for recession. And Miami developers don’t have their head in the sand, condo prices are down, and absorption is down.

Miami has always been attractive to South and Central American buyers, but it’s becoming increasingly more expensive for them.

If you spend more than a month here each year, than the strip, starting at Coconut Grove all the way up to Wynwood—that whole coastline is the new luxury. A lot of people want to be urban, and they want to be near water. Edgewater too—people are riding the coastline all the way up.

I couldn’t be a bigger fan of where luxury is headed in Miami—and I think it’s off the beach.

More: Sotheby’s International Realty Executive Says Customizing a Home is Key

MG: What’s the biggest surprise in the luxury real estate market now?

RS: When you look at what drives luxury markets, the dollar being so high is a problem. The world is kind of on fire at the moment. There’s less disposable income everywhere, and America has become more expensive.

After 2008, real estate was really cheap, but now the dollar is so high, and it makes it difficult for foreign buyers. It’s a good time for Americans who want to buy in America.

But places like San Francisco, New York and Miami, which are global cities, and are driven by foreign buyers, are feeling the strains.

MG: Where are the best luxury homes in the world and why?

RS: The best in the world are in Europe. If luxury is uniqueness and authenticity, it’s there.

I was in Ireland recently, and there were some places we went through that were just gorgeous—houses that overlooked cliffs.

More: Design Firm Chief Says Luxury is About Tapping Into All the Senses

MG: What’s your favorite part of your home?

RS: I love watching football. I’m a big Dolphins fan. I created a room with a custom bar that’s for watching TV. Behind the walls there’s technology, called tiling, that allows me to watch 10 games at once if I want. It was a long, thought-through process.

MG: What best describes the theme to your home and why?

RS: It’s definitely modern. I don’t want to say minimalist, though. It’s a lot of clean architecture with warmth from wood and stone.

MG: What’s the most valuable thing in your home?

RS: My dog, he’s a Portugese water dog named Larry.

But aside from him, my kitchen, which was custom ordered from Poliform. I think they’re some of the best in the world. It faces out, and it has sliding doors called Schüco doors. It’s very indoor/outdoor. You tend to get those in houses, but not condos.

From Penta: Future Returns: Impact Investing in Latin America

MG: What’s the most valuable amenity to have in a home right now?

RS: I’ve always been a fan of doing the basics well—pools, gyms, valet parking, et cetera. Things like ice skating and cigar rooms are too much.

At Echo Brickell we have really good food and beverage, which is great too.

MG: What’s your best piece of real estate advice?

RS: People tend to get hung up on small dollar amounts, and you can’t let your lifestyle suffer because you got a “better” deal somewhere else. It’s an investment vehicle, yes, but you should also want to live there.

MG: What’s going on in the news that will have the biggest impact on the luxury real estate market?

RS: Our president is having an effect on the real estate market. And if we head into a global recession, everything gets affected.

More: Luxury is About Inner Wellness, Says Los Angeles-Based Designer

MG: What is the best area now for investing in luxury properties?

RS: Real estate is trading below cost in a lot of areas. Prices are lowered. It’s worth hopping on a plane and getting shopping.

MG: If you had a choice of living in a new development or a prime resale property, which would you choose and why?

RS: It depends. I really would look at the building as a whole. Some buildings are built well, others aren’t. There’s a lot of badly built buildings out there, and a lot of great ones, too.

When I moved to Miami after living in Chicago, I bought in a building called Epic, because I knew the developer, and it wasn’t brand new. I bought the least expensive apartment in there.

MG: What area currently has the best resale value?

RS: The area that is the new luxury corridor—Brickell, the Eastside, where you’re on the mainland on the water and looking toward the beaches. There’s much more price appreciation. It has a lot to do with flood insurance and the perception of climate change.
